awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Identification and regulatory effects of metabolites responsible for plant immunity
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. As the global population increases, people need affordable and obtainable resources to prevent crop losses. This project will provide researchers and farmers with new bioactive metabolites for protecting crops against plant bacteria. These compounds are expected to be more affordable and less harmful than existing chemicals. As bacteria become resistant to chemical sprays, it is crucial to discover ways to improve crop yields. The premise of this study is to develop novel tools for crop protection that will improve food security. As an underrepresented minority (URM), the Fellow will inspire URM students to develop a passion for plant science. Undergraduate students from The University of Chicago interested in impactful research and graduate school will also be mentored. Both groups will shadow the Fellow through the research project, utilizing various instruments and receiving an introduction  to the finer points of research.

Bacterial infection of crops is a major concern for farmers. Depending on the crop, yield losses can be significant. Research using the model plant Arabidopsis has provided insights into plant-microbe interactions. However, incomplete databases have limited the capabilities of identifying new signaling metabolites that set the basal defense state of Arabidopsis. The goal of this work is to identify metabolite-based natural modulators of plant immunity and the immune-related proteins they regulate. Arabidopsis plants will be exploited to produce high levels of basal metabolites with potent immune-regulatory properties. Mutant and transgenic plants with high levels of such metabolites will be used to discover which immune proteins are affected using a comparative proteomics approach. Metabolite extracts from such plants will be analyzed by chromatography techniques, fractionated, used for bioassays, and characterized by NMR to identify novel immune-modulating metabolites. These discoveries enable researchers to better understand metabolite-protein interactions in disease resistance models and have the potential to provide farmers with new crop protection methods ensuring food security. Many individuals do not realize how the farm to table food chain works. Therefore, the Fellow will also develop a plant science kit in collaboration with an inner-city elementary school in Chicago. This kit will allow students to discover how the farm to table cycle works and why food security is important.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

 

AGD2-Like Defense Response Protein 1 (ALD1), an aminotransferase, may produce plant defense molecules. It has been shown that applying exudates from ALD1-overexpressor (ALD1ox) plants uninfected with bacteria onto wild-type plants infected with bacteria conferred local disease resistance. To characterize these unknown defense molecules, the metabolite profiles of Arabidopsis leaves from wild-type, ALD1ox, and loss-of-function (ald1-T2) plants, as well as exudates from ALD1ox and dexamethasone (dex)-inducible ALD1 (6 lines) genotypes were analyzed by liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (LC-MS) at Washington State University (WSU). After processing the LC-MS raw files in metabolomics algorithms developed within the lab, we tentatively identified eight compounds most likely to have bioactivity. To confirm and further elucidate these eight compounds, the samples were rerun on a high-resolution LC-MS at a USDA ARS lab in Peoria. This analysis confirmed the presence of the compounds initially detected at WSU. Four of the eight compounds were predicted to be glucosinolates. ALD1 has not been shown to affect glucosinolate biosynthesis; thus, an increase in glucosinolate levels may be an indirect effect of ALD1.

 

Follow up analyses by targeted LC-MS/MS using chemical reference standards confirmed the identities of three compounds: glucoerucin, L-phenylalanine, and tuberonic acid. Thus far, the glucosinolate, glucoerucin, has consistently been found to reduce the growth of Pseudomonas syringae pathovar maculicola in Arabidopsis leaves. These results are not unexpected because glucosinolates are known to be involved in plant defense. We also built a database of Arabidopsis metabolites. This database has been added to WSU's open-access Research Exchange platform (DOI: https://doi.org/10.7273/000005297). Due to the nature of the project, we also developed an automated method using natural language processing (NLP) to compare the presence and absence of compounds between two or more sample groups. We tested this novel method on a complex research question and the results, titled: Utilization of a natural language processing-based approach to determine the composition of artifact residues, are in review for publication in BMC Bioinformatics. Therefore, this project not only further elucidated the function of ALD1, but it also led to the development of a novel method for distinguishing relationships between biological samples.

 

With respect to broader impacts, I have partnered with Whittier Primary School in Peoria, a K to 4th grade public school, to demonstrate plant science experiments to 2nd graders. Students at Whittier performed the following seven hands-on experiments: resurrecting a plant, watching plants take up water, extracting DNA from fruit, extracting color-changing pigments from red cabbage, counting tree rings, extracting chlorophyll from leaves, and comparing polystyrene- and starch-based packing peanuts. I used household items for supplies (besides the resurrection plants) so students could later perform these same experiments at home with family members. I also tracked student progress through pre- and post-questionnaires. This will help me gauge how well I am teaching them, and I look forward to improving my experimental procedures with each demonstration.
